title.narrative: 2.2 HEALTH WORKERS HAVE INCREASED CAPACITY TO PROVIDE QUALITY CARE AND TREATMENT

description.narrative: 2.2 Health workers at subnational levels have increased capacity to provide quality care and treatment for/services to SAM children using standard protocols, which contributes to Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition, Early Detection And Treatment Of Malnutrition (Covid), Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 2. Nutrition: By 2022, children including adolescent girls and women of reproductive age have improved and equitable access to and use of adequate nutritious diet and improved nutritional care behaviour and care practices.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 2.2 Health workers at subnational levels have increased capacity to provide quality care and treatment for/services to SAM childrenusing standard protocols

description.narrative: Nepal has sustained and maintained high quality treatment for children 6-59months suffering severe acute malnutrition and there has been an increase in the geographical coverage of treatment services from 58 to 61 districts out of 77 districts. The SPHERE standards for performance quality monitoring by which Nepal’s IMAM;programme is measured against were calculated and based on this, the performance indicators for children recovered, defaulted, and died, indicate high programme performance quality of Nepal’s IMAM programme whereby 80% of children who received treatment (7982 out of 9,936;total discharged), recovered, 1,083 defaulted (11%) and 38 children died (0.4%). | Status:Met | As-of Date:09/01/2022
